appDesc.message: Marks content farm links, prevents accidental visiting, and blocks content farms' ads and mallicious scripts.

permWebRequestBlockingTitle.message: Web request blocking permission not granted
permWebRequestBlockingTitle.description: Title for configuration about webRequestBlocking permission

permWebRequestBlockingDesc.message:
An extension needs a forced installation to support web request blocking in some Chromium-based browsers. When not supported, a web page may not be blocked before loading, and malicious scripts in the web page may have a chance to run successfully.

Windows

Add a new string in the registry:

  • Google Chrome: {main_key}\SOFTWARE\Policies\Google\Chrome\ExtensionInstallForcelist\{num} = {extension_id}
  • Microsoft Edge: {main_key}\SOFTWARE\Policies\Microsoft\Edge\ExtensionInstallForcelist\{num} = {extension_id}
  • Chromium: {main_key}\SOFTWARE\Policies\Chromium\ExtensionInstallForcelist\{num} = {extension_id}

Where {main_key} is either HKEY_CURRENT_USER (for the current user) or HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE (for all users), {num} is any integer, and {extension_id} can be found in the extension management page. Shutdown the browser (including related background processes) and restart it after done.

Other OS

For configuration for another operating system or browser, see the official document:

  • Google Chrome
  • Microsoft Edge
permWebRequestBlockingDesc.description: Description for configuration about webRequestBlocking permission

unblockBtnTitle.description: Title of unblock button in blocked page

unblockBtnPrompt.message:
Information from a content farm is usually unverified and questionable, and malicious ads and/or scripts could reside. Please think carefully before entering.
• Try View if you intend to investigate the page content, and Unlock only for cases that View cannot work as expected. Such sites mostly requires scripts to load and are more likely to contain malicious scripts. Consider browsing with an independent browser, profile, container, or incognito window to reduce the risk.
• Add the URL to the graylist/whitelist (or remove from the blacklist) if you don't think this site is a content farm or you intend not to keep blocking it for any reason.

To still unblock this page temporarily, input the following passcode: $key$
unblockBtnPrompt.description: Prompt message of unblock button in blocked page

helpSyntaxTitle.description: Title of the syntax help page

helpSyntaxContent.message:
1. Standard rules

A standard rule is domain-based, including all subdomains. For example, this rule:

    example.com

matches these pages:

    http://example.com
    https://example.com
    http://example.com:8000
    http://user:password@example.com
    http://example.com/
    http://example.com/somepage.html
    http://example.com/subdir/somepage.html
    http://example.com?id=123
    http://example.com#main

and pages in the "www"-prefixed domain:

    http://www.example.com

and pages in the subdomains:

    http://sub.example.com
    http://extra.sub.example.com

, while these pages are not matched:

    http://nonexample.com
    http://example.com.tw

An IPv4 or IPv6 can also be specified in a standard rule, for example:

    192.168.0.1
    [::ffff:c0a8:1]


2. Wildcards

Wildcards "*" can be included in a standard rule to match zero or more chars. For example, this rule:

    example.com.*

matches these pages:

    http://example.com.tw
    http://example.com.cn
    http://example.com.extra.tw

Wildcards cannot be used when specifying an IPv4 or IPv6.


3. Comments

Text following a space will be ignored. For example, this rule:

    example.com I am the comment

works as same as this rule:

    example.com


4. Regular expression rules

Besides standard rules, a regular expression (RegExp) rule can be used to match a complicated URL. To use it, add "/" at the start and the end of a rule. For example:

    /^https?://example\.com/subdir(?=$|[/?#])/ I am a RegExp rule

Note that a regular expression rule matches whole URL rather than the domain name, and "www"-prefixed domain and subdomains are not included. Besides, "/"s need not be escaped, as the example above has shown.

Modifiers can be appended after the ending "/" of a regular expression rule. For example:

    /^https?://example\\.com/FOO(?=$|[/?#])/i Ignore case


5. Auto-correction

Entered rules will be auto-corrected. A standard rule will be converted to the corresponding domain name. For example, these rules:

    www.example.com
    http://example.com
    example.com:8000
    http://example.com/somepage.html

will be corrected to:

    example.com

Internationalized domain names (IDN) will be converted to punycoded form. For example, this rule:

    中文.tw

will be corrected to:

    xn--fiq228c.tw

If a standard rule cannot be converted to a valid domain name, or a regular expression rule has an invalid syntax, it will be cleared.

If URL transformation rules are specified, input URLs will be transformed using these rules prior to the auto-correction described above.

Rules in a web blacklist are not auto-corrected, invalid ones will be cleared anyway.
helpSyntaxContent.description: Content of the syntax help page

helpTransformSyntaxTitle.description: Title of the transform syntax help page

helpTransformSyntaxContent.message:
URL transformation rules is one rule per line. The syntax of each rule is:

    <pattern> <replacement> <comment>

Where <pattern> is a regular expression (RegExp) enclosed by "/", and <replacement> is any text with "$$" for special meaning:
- "$$$": inserts a "$$".
- "$$n": inserts the nth parenthesized submatch string. (n is a positive integer)
- "$$&": inserts the matched substring.
- "$$`": inserts the portion of the string that precedes the matched substring.
- "$$'": inserts the portion of the string that follows the matched substring.
- If <replacement> is a RegExp (enclosed by "/"), the inserted string will be escaped automatically.

When trnsforming a URL, rules are matched one by one. When a matched <pattern> is found, the URL will be replaced with the corresponding <replacement> and further processing is skipped. If no match is found, the URL is not trnsformed.

For example, the following rule:

    /^https?://example\.com/(.*)/ $$1.example.com

transforms the URL "https://example.com/my.job" into "my.job.example.com".

While the following rule:

    /^https?://example\.com/(.*)/ /^https?://example\.com/$$1/

transforms the URL "https://example.com/my.job" into "/^https?://example\.com/my\.job/".

Transform rules for several sites can be found in “Our blacklists”.
helpTransformSyntaxContent.description: Content of the transform syntax help page
